comment:
You're wrong about the smile. (He didn't exhale. You tried to access his emotional space, and in your mind, it made sense that he'd exhale. He didn't.) He's still partly in love with her. He finds her fit amusing, as destructive as she is, a part of him still finds her exciting and... admirable. He felt pleasure saying she smashed a vodka bottle, "because she's insane/sexy hot"... He knows it's serious, but in truth, he finds it rather hot. Femme fatale, you know? He's lying about his outrage he feels against her. He's not as upset as he says he is, but he knows she's still lying about him, and that he can't allow her to keep doing, but he is more turned on by her fits of anger than threatened by them. Still, what kills him is something different. The hunched shoulders do speak of a feeling of betrayal, yes... Which ties together with his self-loathing of actually loving this POS of a woman.

When he actually gets to the part where the finger gets sliced, no smiling. Now, it's relived concern. Her being angry and volatile, funny, charming, but he speaks of the finger the same way as when kids get hurt while playing a bit rough, it's just that OK, someone got physically injured and that's not funny anymore but concerning - even if it's his own finger. But he does lighten things up with his sense of humor, which is again linked to his ability to see Amber's rages as something rather humorous. He KNOWS this is a contradiction in his mind, but he just can't help thinking this girl is... Exciting and lovable. The sadness comes from the loss of her, when he knows he has to do the sensible thing and divorce her, but he figures he'll always be in love with her - to his own detriment. 

The flashing smiles... He went somewhere else in his mind, something that amused him at the time it happened, before he returns back to the topic. Just a flash of a memory that he played back to himself but didn't comment on, as it was probably irrelevant. Maybe something she said during the argument or right after the accident, some Amber-like attitude she'd take into the events or something. He's thinking of her with pleasure, and that's where the smiles are coming from. (Again, he didn't exhale there, either.)

"It looked like Vesuvius" he flashes a smile again, at his own amusement to the visual of his finger shooting blood. "Having to deal with the insanity..." "... by this woman *smiles, scoffs* I was married to." So there's the first exhale. He doesn't think somehow, that she is fit to be called "a woman". He'd probably refer to her as "a thing", a thing of intrigue and curiosity, but not really a woman. He was also laughing at himself, in the "I sure know how to pick 'em" -effect.

On a side note, the reason why he stammers and stutters, and loses focus is not, as some might assume, drugs, but him running a film in the back of his mind of the events he's supposed to be describing. But like many intelligent people, he can have several films running in there over each other, and he follows tangents here and there just to check them or amuse himself with them. Intelligent people do this, as they know they can get away with a few extracurricular activities and get back into the room after the entertainment is over. His attention shifts between one and the other "memory film", and he has to remind himself of the topic he was actually supposed to be talking about. A little ADHD, that is.

He flashes a smile again in "I didn't want to lose the finger"... He loved the drama of it. He knows it's stupid to, so the conflict of loving the drama and feeling stupid about it result into a smile directed at himself: "you're an ass".

He's less enamored by the fact she says he did it to himself... That's a typical male response to annoying stuff their wives do. Almost like: "She can fight the fight but she can't be honest about it, that's disappointingly feminine of her." So that's what he's not impressed by. "Chop my finger off and I'll laugh but lie about it like a coward and I'll divorce your ass." 

The brushing the hair back, I interpret as disappointment in her, again: "At least do me the COURTESY of LYING BETTER." As in, IF you have to put me through this, at least have some DIGNITY in it by lying so I don't have to be EMBARRASSED by being nailed by your shoddy, bad lies.

Granted I know a lot about JD and his obscure sense of humor, or at least, think I do. :D
